SubTopics: Solve problems involving operations (+, –, ×, and ÷) with whole numbers, decimals (through thousandths), straight computation, or word problems.

Key.Rationale: Cancels the 0.25 from 27.25 and then multiplies 3 • 27.
Finds the sum of the quotients 3 ÷ 0.25 and 27.25 ÷ 0.25.
Multiplies 3 • 27 • 3 • 0.25 and then divides the result (60.75) by 0.25.
Multiplies 3 • 27.25 and then divides the result (81.75) by 0.25.

SubTopics: Represent and/or solve real-world and mathematical problems using rates, ratios, and/or percents.
Content: A family traveled by car to visit a relative.

:box:• The family traveled 114 miles on the route they used going to the relative's home.

• The family used a different route returning from the relative's home and traveled 156 miles.

• The car used a total of 12 gallons of gas.
On average, how many miles did the family travel for each gallon of gas the car used?

Key.Rationale: Multiplies 12 by the quotient 156 ÷ 114.
Divides 114 by half of 12.
Divides the total distance (114 + 156) by the number of gallons (12).
Divides 156 by half of 12.

SubTopics: Use ratio language and notation (such as 3 to 4, 3:4, 3/4) to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.
Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
Content: Jamal and Lucy each build model airplanes.

:box:• Jamal had 10 model airplanes. After building some model airplanes last month, he had 18 model airplanes.

• Lucy also had some model airplanes. Last month, she built 12 model airplanes. After that, she had 20 model airplanes.
Which statement describes the ratio of the number of model airplanes Jamal built last month to the number of model airplanes Lucy built last month?

A.Choice: For every model airplane Jamal built, Lucy built 5 model airplanes.

Key.Rationale: Determines the correct ratio (8 to 12) but “reduces” it using subtraction.

B.Choice: For every 2 model airplanes Jamal built, Lucy built 3 model airplanes.

Key.Rationale: Compares the number of model airplanes Jamal built last month (18 – 10) to the number of model airplanes Lucy built last month (12) and simplifies the ratio 8 to 12 by dividing each number by 4.

C.Choice: For every 2 model airplanes Jamal built, Lucy built 5 model airplanes.

Key.Rationale: Compares the number of model airplanes Jamal built to the total number of airplanes built OR compares the number of model airplanes Jamal built to the total number of airplanes Lucy had.

D.Choice: For every 7 model airplanes Jamal built, Lucy built 3 model airplanes.

Key.Rationale: Compares (18 + 10) to 12 instead of (18 – 10) to 12.

SubTopics: Find the unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b (with b ≠ 0) and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship.
Content: Mike buys 4 packs of baseball cards for a total of $8. Each pack contains 10 baseball cards. How much does Mike pay for each baseball card?

Key.Rationale: Reverses the order of the division when determining the amount paid for each pack and calculates (4 ÷ 8) ÷ 10.

Determines the amount paid for each pack by dividing the total amount by the number of packs ($8 ÷ 4) and then determines the amount paid for each card by dividing the amount per pack by the number of cards in each pack ($2 ÷ 10) OR determines the total number of cards purchased by multiplying the number of packs by the number of cards in each pack (4 • 10) and then determines the amount paid for each card by dividing the amount paid by the total number of cards ($8 ÷ 40).
Uses multiplication instead of division when determining the amount paid for each pack and calculates (8 • 4) ÷ 10.
Determines the total number of cards purchased but reverses the order of the division when determining the amount paid for each card (40 ÷ 8).

SubTopics: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Determine the area of triangles and special quadrilaterals (i.e., square, rectangle, parallelogram, rhombus, and trapezoid).
Content: Mr. Li's yard is in the shape of a square. Each side has a length of 40 feet. Mr. Li uses 20% of the area of the yard for a garden. What is the area, in square feet, of the garden in Mr. Li's yard?

Key.Rationale: Determines 20% of each side length (0.20 • 40 = 8) and then multiplies 8 by 8.
Divides the area of the yard (40 • 40) by 20.
Converts 20% to 0.20 before multiplying the area of the yard (40 • 40) by 0.20.
Divides the area of the yard (40 • 40) by 2.

SubTopics: Identify, write, and evaluate numerical and algebraic expressions.
Content: Which statement explains why −2x + 4y = 7 is not an expression?

A.Choice: An expression cannot have an equals sign.

Key.Rationale: Recognizes that a comparison symbol (=) is used to compare two expressions.

B.Choice: An expression cannot have an operation symbol.

Key.Rationale: Thinks expressions can have only 1 term or can compare only 2 terms.

C.Choice: An expression cannot have any negative numbers.

Key.Rationale: Thinks expressions can have only positive numbers.

D.Choice: An expression cannot have more than one variable.

Key.Rationale: Thinks expressions can have only 1 variable.

SubTopics: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to 2 × 2 × 2 × 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 × 7 × 7?

Key.Rationale: Uses 2 as the exponent of base 2 instead of 3.
Counts three 2s and rewrites 2 × 2 × 2 as 2³, counts four 3s and rewrites 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 as 3⁴, and counts two 7s and rewrites 7 × 7 as 7².
Switches the bases and the exponents.
Multiplies the bases while also including the exponents.

SubTopics: Identify parts of an expression using mathematical terms (e.g., sum, term, product, factor, quotient, coefficient, quantity).
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.
Content: Lynda builds a wooden box in the shape of a rectangular prism. The box has no cover. The box is 12 inches long, x inches wide, and 24 inches high. The expression below can be used to determine the surface area, in square inches, of the box.
What is the coefficient of the term in the expression that represents the area of the bottom of the box?

Key.Rationale: Identifies the smaller factor of the length-height product, which represents two faces of the prism.

Identifies 12x as the term that represents the area of the bottom of the box since it is the only face that is not being doubled (“the top has no cover”) and then identifies 12 as the coefficient of the variable x.
Identifies the coefficient of the width-height product, which represents two faces of the prism.
Identifies the larger factor of the length-height product, which represents two faces of the prism.

SubTopics: Create, solve, and interpret one-variable equations or inequalities in real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: An inequality is shown below.
Which equation has a solution that satisfies the inequality?

Key.Rationale: <ultiplies both sides of the equation by the reciprocal of 3/4 and determines that x = 16, which is less than 20.
Identifies an equation with a solution that is equal to 20 instead of less than 20.
Subtracts 12 1/2 from 21.2 instead of adding.
Simplifies 2³ as 2 • 3 and then adds the result to 2.2 • 6 (13.2 + 6).

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
Content: A pizza was cut into equal slices. Ben ate 4 of the slices. The amount Ben ate was 2/3 of the whole pizza. Which equation represents a way to find the total number of slices that were in the whole pizza?

Key.Rationale: Recognizes that the total number of slices should be multiplied by 2/3 to show that 2/3 of a whole pizza is 4 slices.
Multiplies x by 4 instead of by 2/3.
Uses addition instead of multiplication.
Multiplies 4 by 2/3 instead of x by 2/3.

SubTopics: Represent and analyze quantitative relationships between dependent and independent variables.
Content: Mr. Kusick unpacks full boxes of textbooks to get ready for the school year. Each full box contains the same number of textbooks. The table below shows the numbers of textbooks that Mr. Kusick unpacks from different numbers of boxes.
problems/PA22G6M/media/11a.jpg
Which statement about this relation is true?

A.Choice: The number of boxes is the dependent variable because it is the first column in the table.

Key.Rationale: Considers that the order of the columns determines which variable is the dependent variable.

B.Choice: The number of boxes is the dependent variable because it is the smaller number in each row.

Key.Rationale: Considers the dependent variable to always be the smaller set of values.

C.Choice: The number of textbooks is the dependent variable because each number of textbooks is a multiple of the number of boxes in the same row.

Key.Rationale: Considers the dependent variable to always be a multiple of the independent variable.

D.Choice: The number of textbooks is the dependent variable because it is determined by the number of boxes Mr. Kusick unpacks.

Key.Rationale: Recognizes that the number of textbooks is the dependent variable because the number of textbooks that have been unpacked is determined by (i.e., is “dependent” upon) the number of boxes that have been unpacked.

SubTopics: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
Content: Lara runs 2 miles each day. She uses the equation shown below to help determine some information about her running.
2x = y
What do the variables x and y most likely represent in Lara's equation?

A.Choice: The variable x represents the total number of miles Lara runs in y days.

Key.Rationale: Switches the meanings of the variables.

B.Choice: The variable y represents the total number of miles Lara runs in x days.

Key.Rationale: Recognizes that the total number of miles Lara runs is 2 times the number of days, so identifies x as the number of days since the x is being multiplied by 2 in the equation.

C.Choice: The variable x represents Lara's rate, in miles per hour, and the variable y represents the total time, in hours, she runs each day.

Key.Rationale: Uses the equation d = rt and describes it as d = xy.

D.Choice: The variable y represents Lara's rate, in miles per hour, and the variable x represents the total time, in hours, she runs each day.

Key.Rationale: Uses the equation d = rt and describes it as d = yx.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of statistical variability by summarizing and describing distributions.
Content: Which line plot shows a data distribution that has the same range and interquartile range?

Key.Rationale: Considers that the range and interquartile range would be the same when a symmetric data set is somewhat spread out.
Considers that the range and interquartile range would be the same when all the data points are unique.
Considers that the range and interquartile range would be the same when a symmetric data set is clustered in the center.

Recognizes that a data set that is distributed equally over only two unique values has the same range and interquartile range OR determines the range of the data set to be 2 by subtracting the minimum value from the maximum value (6 – 4) and determines the interquartile range to also be 2 by first identifying the first and third quartile values (the first quartile value is the average of the 2nd and 3rd smallest data points, (4 + 4)/2 = 4; the third quartile value is the average of the 6th and 7th smallest data points, (6 + 6)/2 = 6) and then subtracting the first quartile value from the third quartile value (6 – 4).

SubTopics: Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.
Content: Carter is a quarterback for a football team. The list below shows the number of yards his team gained on his last 10 completed passes.
Which line plot also shows the number of yards Carter's team gained on his last 10 completed passes?

Key.Rationale: Does not plot the negative values.
Plots the negative values as positive values.
Does not plot repeated values.
Extends the number line below 0 to include the negative numbers and uses one × for each number, including three ×s for 3 and two ×s for 6.

SubTopics: Describe any overall pattern and any deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.
Content: The line plot below shows the weights, in pounds, of twelve bowling balls on a rack.
problems/PA22G6M/media/15a.jpg
Which statement about the weights of these bowling balls is true?

A.Choice: The weights cluster from 8 pounds to 10 pounds, and 8 pounds is an outlier.

Key.Rationale: Concludes that 8 is an outlier since there is only one value at that weight.

B.Choice: The weights cluster from 11 pounds to 15 pounds, and 8 pounds is an outlier.

Key.Rationale: Confuses definitions of cluster and gap and concludes that 8 is an outlier since there is only one value at that weight.

C.Choice: The weights cluster from 8 pounds to 10 pounds, and 16 pounds is an outlier.

Key.Rationale: Identifies that 11 of the 12 data points are grouped (i.e., “clustered”) together from 8 pounds to 10 pounds and identifies the 16-pound weight as an outlier since it is significantly greater than the other data values (i.e., it is more than 1.5 times the interquartile range above the third quartile value, since Q1 = 9, Q3 = 10, IQR = 10 – 9 = 1, 1.5 • 1 = 1.5, 9 + 1.5 = 10.5, and 16 > 10.5).

D.Choice: The weights cluster from 11 pounds to 15 pounds, and 16 pounds is an outlier.

Key.Rationale: Confuses definitions of cluster and gap.

SubTopics: Determine the area of irregular or compound polygons.
Determine the volume of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths.
Determine the surface area of triangular and rectangular prisms (including cubes).
Content: Devonte bought a kite that needs to be put together. When finished, the kite will look like the diagram shown below.
problems/PA22G6M/media/16a.jpg
What is the area, in square inches, of the kite when it is put together?
The box that the kite came in is a rectangular prism with dimensions of 20 1/2 inches by 9 1/2 inches by 2 inches.
What is the surface area, in square inches, of the box? Show or explain all your work.

Miriam bought a kite that is already put together. It is the same size as Devonte's kite. The box that Miriam's kite came in is a rectangular prism with dimensions of 32 1/2 inches by 18 1/2 inches by 1 inch. Miriam thinks that since both her kite and Devonte's kite are the same size, the volumes of the boxes they came in are the same.
Show or explain why Miriam is 𝗡𝗢𝗧 correct. As part of your response, find the correct volume, in cubic inches, of each box.
Devonte's box: :FR-1:
Miriam's box: :FR-2:
